title: Enhanced Electron Backscatter Correction for Electron Probe Microanalysis
content: Electron probe microanalysis (EPMA) is an element identification technique which generates and records the wavelength of released characteristic x-ray radiation from a given sample. For a quantitative measurement of the relative proportion of elements, we need to correct for the backscattering of incident electrons out of the sample. These lost electrons cannot produce further x-rays, so a sample with significant backscattering will have lower intensity characteristic peaks, underestimating the amount of the element in the sample. To account for this, microanalysts calculate a backscatter correction in terms of an (iteratively determined) average atomic number Z¯ for the specimen. A typical approach, dating back to the dawn of the field [1], uses the mass concentration ci to weight components in calculating the average Z¯. This is a flawed approach that works best when constituent elements have approximately the same ratio A/Zof atomic weight to atomic number [2]. Low-Z elements, however, have largely varying A/Z ratios: H, He, C, N, and O are almost exactly A/Z=2, but the A/Z ratios of Li, Be, B, and F range between 2.111 and 2.313.
